title: On Evolution-Based Models for Experimentation Under Interference
summary: This paper proposes an evolution-based modeling approach to estimate population-level causal effects in networked systems where interference pathways are largely unobserved. It argues that instead of recovering exact network structures, characterizing how interactions evolve outcomes through recursive equations is sufficient, leveraging treatment randomization to learn heterogeneous spillover effects.

title: Revolutionizing Glioma Segmentation & Grading Using 3D MRI - Guided Hybrid Deep Learning Models
summary: This paper introduces a novel hybrid deep learning model for the precise 3D segmentation and accurate grading of gliomas from MRI data. The framework integrates a U-Net based segmentation network with a hybrid DenseNet-VGG classification network, both enhanced by multihead and spatial-channel attention mechanisms. It achieves a 98% Dice coefficient for segmentation and 99% classification accuracy, outperforming traditional deep learning approaches.

title: Geometric Confinement Reveals Scale-Free Velocity Correlations in Epithelial Cell Monolayer
summary: This research reveals that epithelial cell monolayers exhibit scale-free velocity correlations, challenging the concept of a single intrinsic correlation length and suggesting critical-like system behavior with long-range information transmission. The study demonstrates that geometric confinement, substrate rigidity, and boundary conditions significantly influence collective cell flows, mechanical fields, and vimentin distribution during tissue maturation.

title: Fast 3D Ultrasound Localization Microscopy via Projection-based Processing Framework
summary: This paper introduces a novel projection-based processing framework for 3D Ultrasound Localization Microscopy (ULM) that significantly reduces computational demands while maintaining high image quality. By reformulating complex 3D ULM processing steps into efficient 2D operations, the framework enables rapid reconstruction of vascular images, demonstrating potential for real-time feedback during clinical scans. This advancement addresses the current bottleneck of slow post-processing and high computational cost in 3D ULM, making it more viable for widespread clinical application.

title: TAB-DRW: A DFT-based Robust Watermark for Generative Tabular Data
summary: TAB-DRW addresses the critical need for traceability and misuse prevention in high-fidelity synthetic tabular data generated by AI, particularly relevant in sensitive sectors like healthcare. It proposes an efficient and robust post-editing watermarking scheme that embeds signals in the frequency domain using Discrete Fourier Transform (DFT) and a novel rank-based pseudorandom bit generation. Experiments confirm its strong detectability and robustness against common post-processing attacks, while preserving high data fidelity and fully supporting mixed-type features.

title: Approximate Bayesian Computation Made Easy: A Practical Guide to ABC-SMC for Dynamical Systems with \texttt{pymc}
summary: Mechanistic models are essential tools across ecology, epidemiology, and the life sciences, but parameter inference remains challenging when likelihood functions are intractable. Approximate Bayesian Computation with Sequential Monte Carlo (ABC-SMC) offers a powerful likelihood-free alternative that...

title: Deep Learning-Based Multiclass Classification of Oral Lesions with Stratified Augmentation
summary: This research proposes a deep learning-based multiclass classifier for differentiating sixteen types of oral lesions, aiming to improve early diagnosis of oral cancer. It addresses common challenges of limited and imbalanced datasets by implementing stratified data splitting combined with advanced data augmentation and oversampling techniques. The model achieved strong performance metrics (83.33% accuracy, 89.12% precision, 77.31% recall) and demonstrated superiority over existing state-of-the-art methods, particularly in classifying minority classes.

title: Enhanced Landmark Detection Model in Pelvic Fluoroscopy using 2D/3D Registration Loss
summary: This paper introduces a novel deep learning framework to enhance automated landmark detection in pelvic fluoroscopy, specifically addressing the challenge of variable patient or imaging unit orientation. It integrates a 2D/3D landmark registration loss directly into the training of a U-Net model, aiming to improve detection accuracy and robustness under realistic intra-operative conditions. The study analyzes the performance of this approach against baseline U-Net models.

title: Some aspects of robustness in modern Markov Chain Monte Carlo
summary: This review paper examines the critical issue of robustness in modern Markov Chain Monte Carlo (MCMC) algorithms, which are widely used for approximating intractable probability distributions. It specifically focuses on two prevalent pathologies—roughness and flatness—that can severely impair the practical efficiency and reliability of standard MCMC methods. The authors categorize and discuss various algorithmic remedies proposed in the literature for these challenges, outlining a path for future research in developing more dependable MCMC tools.

title: Machine Learning Approaches to Clinical Risk Prediction: Multi-Scale Temporal Alignment in Electronic Health Records
summary: This study introduces the Multi-Scale Temporal Alignment Network (MSTAN) to address critical challenges in Electronic Health Records (EHR) data, such as temporal irregularity and multi-scale dynamic dependencies, for enhanced clinical risk prediction. MSTAN employs a learnable temporal alignment mechanism and multi-scale convolutional feature extraction to effectively model both long-term trends and short-term fluctuations in patient data. Experimental results demonstrate its superior performance compared to mainstream baselines across multiple evaluation metrics on publicly available EHR datasets.

title: The Age-specific Alzheimer 's Disease Prediction with Characteristic Constraints in Nonuniform Time Span
summary: This study introduces an innovative methodology for age-specific Alzheimer's Disease (AD) prediction by generating sequential MRI images, specifically addressing challenges posed by irregular time-interval data. It leverages quantitative metrics and an age-scaling factor to ensure accurate representation of disease characteristics and facilitate prediction of advanced AD stages. The findings indicate that these novel components significantly enhance the accuracy and iterative quality of MRI synthesis, achieving high structural similarity for long-term prognosis.

title: Self-Paced Learning for Images of Antinuclear Antibodies
summary: This paper introduces a novel self-paced learning framework for automated Antinuclear Antibody (ANA) detection from unaltered microscope images, specifically designed to address the complex multi-instance, multi-label (MIML) nature of this diagnostic task. By integrating an instance sampler, a probabilistic pseudo-label dispatcher, and self-paced weight learning, the framework mimics human labeling logic to identify consistent ANA sub-regions and assign aggregated labels. It significantly outperforms prior methods, achieving state-of-the-art results on ANA datasets and strong performance on public medical MIML benchmarks, streamlining a crucial diagnostic process for autoimmune disorders.

title: Lost in Time? A Meta-Learning Framework for Time-Shift-Tolerant Physiological Signal Transformation
summary: ShiftSyncNet is a novel meta-learning framework designed to overcome temporal misalignment in transforming non-invasive physiological signals like PPG and BCG into clinically meaningful signals such as arterial blood pressure (ABP). This framework automatically learns and corrects time shifts using a bi-level optimization approach with Fourier phase shifts, significantly improving transformation accuracy and label quality compared to existing methods. Its effectiveness was demonstrated with substantial performance gains across multiple datasets.

title: A Dynamic Anti-Equinus Orthosis with Electromyography Sensor for Neuromuscular Rehabilitation
summary: This study introduces EquiSay, a dynamic anti-equinus orthosis equipped with an anterior elastic tension system and an EMG sensor for real-time tibialis anterior muscle activation monitoring. It leverages AI, including a U-Net model for synthetic EMG data generation and a predictive framework for threshold calibration, addressing data limitations. Experimental results show EquiSay significantly improves dorsiflexion, enhances patient satisfaction, and provides valuable clinical insights for neuromuscular rehabilitation.

title: Conversational no-code and multi-agentic disease module identification and drug repurposing prediction with ChatDRex
summary: ChatDRex is a conversational, multi-agent AI system designed to democratize network-based drug repurposing prediction by providing natural language access to complex bioinformatics analyses. It integrates an extensive biomedical knowledge graph (NeDRex) and specialized agents to enable non-experts to identify disease modules and predict drug repurposing candidates. The system aims to accelerate therapeutic discovery, advance personalized medicine, and foster translational research.

title: Anomaly Detection with Adaptive and Aggressive Rejection for Contaminated Training Data
summary: This paper introduces Adaptive and Aggressive Rejection (AAR), a novel anomaly detection method designed to robustly handle contaminated training data without relying on fixed contamination ratios. AAR dynamically excludes anomalies using modified z-scores and Gaussian mixture model-based thresholds, employing both hard and soft rejection strategies. Experiments demonstrate AAR significantly improves performance by 0.041 AUROC compared to state-of-the-art methods, enhancing reliability for real-world applications in domains like healthcare.

title: The Directed Prediction Change - Efficient and Trustworthy Fidelity Assessment for Local Feature Attribution Methods
summary: This paper introduces the Directed Prediction Change (DPC) metric, a novel and efficient method for assessing the fidelity of local feature attribution methods in machine learning. DPC significantly improves upon existing metrics like Infidelity by providing a deterministic evaluation with an almost tenfold speedup, which is crucial for building trustworthy AI explanations in high-stakes applications like medicine.

title: Stopping power monitoring during proton therapy by means of prompt gamma timing: first experimental results with a homogeneous phantom
summary: This research introduces Spatiotemporal Emission Reconstruction from Prompt-Gamma Timing (SER-PGT) as a novel method to monitor proton stopping power and range during proton therapy, aiming to reduce treatment uncertainties. The study presents the first experimental results demonstrating SER-PGT's feasibility, achieving an 8% average error in stopping power estimation and a 3 mm standard deviation in range shift detection using a homogeneous phantom. These findings highlight the potential for real-time, in-vivo dose verification in proton therapy.

title: SurgMLLMBench: A Multimodal Large Language Model Benchmark Dataset for Surgical Scene Understanding
summary: SurgMLLMBench introduces a novel, unified multimodal benchmark dataset addressing the limitations of existing surgical datasets for evaluating interactive large language models (LLMs) in surgical scene understanding. It integrates pixel-level instrument segmentation masks and structured Visual Question Answering (VQA) annotations across diverse surgical domains under a unified taxonomy, demonstrating consistent cross-domain performance and effective generalization for models trained on it.

title: Estimation in high-dimensional linear regression: Post-Double-Autometrics as an alternative to Post-Double-Lasso
summary: This paper introduces Post-Double-Autometrics (PDA) as a novel method for high-dimensional linear regression, designed to accurately estimate parameters of interest like average treatment effects. PDA is presented as a superior alternative to Post-Double-Lasso (PDL), mitigating the substantial omitted variable bias often encountered with PDL in finite sample settings. The methodology yields more reliable estimates, demonstrating improved performance over existing techniques.

title: Maxitive Donsker-Varadhan Formulation for Possibilistic Variational Inference
summary: This paper introduces a novel "Maxitive Donsker-Varadhan Formulation" for possibilistic variational inference, aiming to address the limitations of traditional probabilistic VI when dealing with intractable high-dimensional integrals and subjective probabilities. By leveraging possibility theory, this framework directly models epistemic uncertainty, offering enhanced robustness and interpretability, particularly for sparse or imprecise data. The authors develop this principled formulation by adapting core VI concepts like entropy and divergence to a possibilistic setting, applying it to exponential-family functions and revealing unique mathematical structures.
domains: Prognostics and Risk Assessment (incomplete patient profiles)

title: Behavior-induced oscillations in epidemic outbreaks with distributed memory: beyond the linear chain trick using numerical methods
summary: This research paper introduces a novel model demonstrating that human behavior adaptation, driven by continuously distributed memory of past infection cases, can solely induce sustained, oscillatory epidemic waves. Utilizing advanced numerical methods, the study provides insights into how the shape of the 'memory kernel' and the level of minimal contact influence the period, peak, and stability of these behavior-induced outbreaks, moving beyond previous analytical limitations.

title: Learning Cell-Aware Hierarchical Multi-Modal Representations for Robust Molecular Modeling
summary: This paper introduces CHMR (Cell-aware Hierarchical Multi-modal Representations), a novel framework for robust molecular property prediction that addresses limitations in existing methods by jointly modeling local-global dependencies between molecules and cellular responses. CHMR uniquely captures latent biological hierarchies using a tree-structured vector quantization module, leading to significant performance improvements (3.6% for classification, 17.2% for regression) over state-of-the-art baselines across 728 tasks.

title: Deformation-aware Temporal Generation for Early Prediction of Alzheimers Disease
summary: This paper introduces the Deformation-Aware Temporal Generative Network (DATGN), a novel deep learning model designed to automate the learning and prediction of morphological brain changes associated with Alzheimer's disease (AD) progression. DATGN addresses missing data in MRI sequences, generates future MRI images reflecting disease-specific atrophy, and significantly improves early AD prediction accuracy when its synthetic data is used for classification.

title: Interpretable Fair Clustering
summary: This paper introduces an interpretable and fair clustering framework that embeds fairness constraints directly into decision tree structures, addressing the critical lack of transparency in existing fair clustering methods. The proposed approach not only achieves competitive clustering performance and improved fairness but also offers inherent interpretability and robust handling of multiple sensitive attributes, enabling more equitable and transparent data analysis. A practical variant is also presented, eliminating the need for fairness hyperparameter tuning through a post-pruning strategy.

title: Aligning LLMs with Biomedical Knowledge using Balanced Fine-Tuning
summary: This paper introduces Balanced Fine-Tuning (BFT), an efficient post-training method designed to align Large Language Models (LLMs) with complex biomedical knowledge from sparse data without external reward signals. BFT utilizes a novel two-layer weighting mechanism, significantly outperforming standard Supervised Fine-Tuning (SFT) in medical and biological reasoning tasks and enabling broad applications of LLMs in life science research. Its ability to internalize fragmented scientific knowledge more effectively makes LLMs more reliable for critical biomedical applications.

title: Long-Term Alzheimers Disease Prediction: A Novel Image Generation Method Using Temporal Parameter Estimation with Normal Inverse Gamma Distribution on Uneven Time Series
summary: This research introduces the Temporal Normal Inverse Gamma (T-NIG) model, a novel image generation method for long-term Alzheimer's Disease (AD) prediction. T-NIG addresses the challenge of maintaining disease-related characteristics when dealing with irregular time intervals in sequential brain imaging data by estimating a temporal parameter within a Normal Inverse Gamma Distribution. The model demonstrates state-of-the-art performance in forecasting AD progression while preserving critical disease features across varying time horizons.

title: AerialMind: Towards Referring Multi-Object Tracking in UAV Scenarios
summary: This paper introduces AerialMind, the first large-scale benchmark dataset for Referring Multi-Object Tracking (RMOT) in Unmanned Aerial Vehicle (UAV) scenarios, addressing the current limitation of RMOT research primarily being confined to ground-level environments. It proposes an innovative semi-automated annotation framework called COALA to efficiently build the dataset and a novel method, HawkEyeTrack (HETrack), to enhance vision-language representation learning for improved perception in UAV contexts. The research aims to bridge a critical gap, enabling intelligent aerial systems to perform precise object detection and tracking using natural language instructions.

title: LungNoduleAgent: A Collaborative Multi-Agent System for Precision Diagnosis of Lung Nodules
summary: LungNoduleAgent is an innovative collaborative multi-agent system designed for precision diagnosis of lung nodules from CT scans, addressing limitations in current multimodal LLMs regarding accurate nodule description and medical expertise integration. It streamlines the diagnostic process through three sequential modules—Nodule Spotter, Radiologist, and Doctor Agent System—to identify nodules, generate comprehensive CT reports, and perform malignancy reasoning. Extensive testing shows LungNoduleAgent outperforms mainstream models, emphasizing the critical role of region-level semantic alignment and multi-agent collaboration.

title: Privacy-Preserving Federated Vision Transformer Learning Leveraging Lightweight Homomorphic Encryption in Medical AI
summary: This paper presents a privacy-preserving federated learning framework that combines Vision Transformers (ViT) with lightweight homomorphic encryption (HE) for secure multi-institutional medical image classification. By encrypting compact ViT CLS tokens instead of full gradients, the approach significantly reduces communication overhead and effectively prevents sensitive patient data reconstruction attacks. It achieves high classification accuracy for lung cancer histopathology while maintaining strong privacy guarantees and enabling encrypted inference.

title: BUSTR: Breast Ultrasound Text Reporting with a Descriptor-Aware Vision-Language Model
summary: BUSTR proposes a novel multitask vision-language framework for automated breast ultrasound (BUS) radiology report generation (RRG) that overcomes the critical limitation of requiring paired image-report datasets. By generating reports from structured descriptors and radiomics features, utilizing a descriptor-aware Swin encoder and a dual-level vision-language alignment loss, BUSTR significantly improves both natural language generation and clinical efficacy metrics, particularly for key diagnostic targets like BI-RADS classification and pathology.

title: Stabilizing Fractional Dynamical Networks Suppresses Epileptic Seizures
summary: This paper introduces a novel state-of-the-art method that effectively suppresses epileptic seizure activity by stabilizing fractional dynamical networks modeled from intracranial EEG (iEEG) data. The technique successfully suppressed 34 out of 35 spontaneous seizures with a 49% average amplitude reduction in controlled signals, while also distinguishing four epileptic brain states based on fractal behavior and stability properties.

title: Fusion of classical and quantum kernels enables accurate and robust two-sample tests
summary: This paper introduces MMD-FUSE, a novel hybrid two-sample testing strategy that fuses classical and quantum kernels to improve the accuracy and robustness of statistical tests, particularly for small and high-dimensional datasets. The approach leverages Maximum Mean Discrepancy (MMD) within the Reproducing Kernel Hilbert Space (RKHS) framework, enhancing test power and adaptability across diverse data characteristics. The study demonstrates MMD-FUSE's superior performance over classical counterparts, highlighting its potential for more effective statistical analysis in data-limited scenarios.

title: A deep learning model to reduce agent dose for contrast-enhanced MRI of the cerebellopontine angle cistern
summary: This study developed and evaluated a deep learning (DL) model to significantly reduce the contrast agent dose required for T1-weighted contrast-enhanced MRI (T1ce) of the cerebellopontine angle (CPA) cistern. The DL model successfully restored high-quality images from simulated low-dose acquisitions, enabling lesion detection and diagnostic characterization with only 10% to 30% of the standard contrast agent dose, as validated by both quantitative metrics and radiologist evaluation.

title: Exploring Time-Step Size in Reinforcement Learning for Sepsis Treatment
summary: This paper empirically investigates the impact of time-step size in reinforcement learning (RL) for sepsis treatment, challenging the conventional 4-hour data aggregation. Through controlled experiments comparing 1, 2, 4, and 8-hour time steps, the study demonstrates that finer time-step sizes (1h and 2h) coupled with a static behavior policy yield superior and more stable performance. The work underscores time-step size as a critical design choice in offline RL for healthcare, advocating for the adoption of finer temporal resolutions in sepsis management.

title: Immunometabolic Gatekeeping: Reconciling Peto's & the T-cell Infiltration Prognostic Paradox
summary: This paper introduces an "immunometabolic gatekeeping" framework, positing that a host tissue's intrinsic metabolic intensity and waste-handling capacity are upstream determinants of anti-tumor immunity and cancer vulnerability, rather than solely tumor-intrinsic factors. It integrates evidence from human cancers and cross-species comparisons to reconcile several paradoxes, arguing that metabolically intense tissues create immune-exhausting niches even before malignant transformation.

title: Symbiotic Brain-Machine Drawing via Visual Brain-Computer Interfaces
summary: This paper introduces a novel non-invasive brain-computer interface (BCI) for "mind-drawing" that reconstructs imagined shapes by analyzing steady-state visual evoked potentials (SSVEPs) from single-channel EEG data in approximately two minutes. By adaptively presenting flicker-frequency encoded visual probes and integrating stable diffusion models, the system significantly enhances BCI bit-rates through symbiotic human-AI interaction, transforming mental images into detailed visual representations.

title: RefTr: Recurrent Refinement of Confluent Trajectories for 3D Vascular Tree Centerline Graphs
summary: This paper introduces RefTr, a novel 3D image-to-graph model that generates vascular tree centerlines by recurrently refining 'confluent trajectories'. RefTr achieves superior recall and comparable precision to existing state-of-the-art methods while significantly reducing model parameters and inference time, promising more accurate and efficient analysis of complex anatomical structures in medical imaging.

title: A statistical framework for comparing epidemic forests
summary: This paper introduces the first statistical framework for formally comparing different sets of plausible transmission trees, known as 'epidemic forests', a critical missing tool in outbreak analysis. Using a chi-square test and permutational multivariate analysis of variance (PERMANOVA), the authors demonstrate that PERMANOVA consistently outperforms the chi-square test in sensitivity across various epidemic and forest sizes, providing a robust method implemented in the `mixtree` R package.

title: Adversarial Multi-Task Learning for Liver Tumor Segmentation, Dynamic Enhancement Regression, and Classification
summary: This paper introduces MTI-Net, a novel adversarial multi-task learning framework designed for the simultaneous execution of liver tumor segmentation, dynamic enhancement regression, and classification from MRI data. MTI-Net addresses the challenges of inter-task relevance and dynamic MRI information extraction through specialized modules like Multi-domain Information Entropy Fusion and a task interaction module. Demonstrated high performance on 238 subjects indicates its significant potential for clinical liver tumor assessment.

title: MedROV: Towards Real-Time Open-Vocabulary Detection Across Diverse Medical Imaging Modalities
summary: MedROV introduces the first real-time, open-vocabulary object detection (OVOD) model for medical imaging, addressing the limitations of traditional closed-set detectors and the scarcity of OVOD-specific medical datasets. By curating a large multi-modal dataset (Omnis), employing pseudo-labeling, and leveraging pre-trained foundation models, MedROV achieves significant performance gains (40 mAP50 over SOTA foundation model, >3 mAP50 over closed-set) at 70 FPS, setting a new benchmark for medical detection. This enables the detection of both known and novel medical structures across diverse imaging modalities.

title: The Driver-Blindness Phenomenon: Why Deep Sequence Models Default to Autocorrelation in Blood Glucose Forecasting
summary: This paper introduces the "Driver-Blindness phenomenon," observing that deep sequence models for blood glucose (BG) forecasting consistently fail to leverage clinically informative drivers like insulin, meals, and activity. It formalizes this failure using $Δ_{	ext{drivers}}$, the performance gain from multivariate models over univariate baselines, which is typically near zero in the literature. The authors attribute Driver-Blindness to architectural biases favoring autocorrelation, data fidelity gaps, and physiological heterogeneity, while synthesizing strategies for partial mitigation and recommending routine reporting of $Δ_{	ext{drivers}}$.

title: Assessing LLMs' Performance: Insights from the Chinese Pharmacist Exam
summary: This study evaluated and compared the performance of two large language models, ChatGPT-4o and DeepSeek-R1, on 2,306 multiple-choice questions from the Chinese Pharmacist Licensing Examination (2017-2021). DeepSeek-R1 significantly outperformed ChatGPT-4o (90.0% vs. 76.1%, p < 0.001), demonstrating robust alignment with the exam's structural and semantic demands. The findings highlight the potential of domain-specific LLMs for AI-enabled formative evaluation in medical contexts, while emphasizing the continued necessity of human oversight.

title: Real-time 3D Ultrasonic Needle Tracking with a Photoacoustic Beacon
summary: This paper introduces a novel interventional ultrasound system designed for real-time 3D tracking and B-mode guidance of a core biopsy needle featuring an embedded photoacoustic beacon. The system aims to overcome limitations of poor needle visibility and 2D guidance in conventional ultrasound, providing clinicians with precise, volumetric visualization of the needle tip's location. Performance was validated in phantom studies, and usability assessed by clinicians, indicating its potential to enhance procedure safety and efficiency.

title: FRAGMENTA: End-to-end Fragmentation-based Generative Model with Agentic Tuning for Drug Lead Optimization
summary: FRAGMENTA introduces an end-to-end generative AI framework for drug lead optimization, addressing challenges of limited data and slow model tuning by jointly optimizing molecular fragmentation and generation using dynamic Q-learning. It integrates an agentic AI system that refines objectives through conversational expert feedback, aiming to automate the tuning process. In cancer drug discovery, the Human-Agent configuration identified nearly twice as many high-scoring molecules as baselines, and the autonomous Agent-Agent system outperformed traditional Human-Human tuning.

title: The Text Aphasia Battery (TAB): A Clinically-Grounded Benchmark for Aphasia-Like Deficits in Language Models
summary: This paper introduces the Text Aphasia Battery (TAB), a novel text-only benchmark adapted from the Quick Aphasia Battery, designed to assess aphasia-like deficits in large language models (LLMs). It details the TAB's design, subtests, and scoring, alongside validating an automated evaluation protocol using Gemini 2.5 Flash that shows reliability comparable to expert human raters. The TAB thus provides a clinically-grounded, scalable framework for computationally studying linguistic disorders.

title: Generative Modeling with Manifold Percolation
summary: This paper proposes a novel framework for analyzing generative models by reframing the task as disentangling geometric support from the probability distribution using Continuum Percolation. It establishes an isomorphism between topological phase transitions in Random Geometric Graphs and high-dimensional data manifolds, introducing a 'Percolation Shift metric' that effectively identifies structural pathologies like implicit mode collapse where statistical metrics fail. By translating this topological insight into a differentiable loss function, the approach prevents manifold shrinkage and drives models towards 'Hyper-Generalization,' achieving high fidelity and verified topological expansion.
domains: Medical Imaging (e.g., synthetic MRI, CT, X-ray generation for data augmentation or privacy-preserving datasets)
Drug Discovery (e.g., generating novel molecular structures with diverse properties)
Synthetic Healthcare Data (e.g., creating realistic patient records for privacy-preserving research or clinical trial simulation)
Computational Pathology (e.g., generating diverse tissue samples for AI training)
Personalized Medicine (e.g., modeling diverse patient responses to treatments)

title: A Physics-Informed Loss Function for Boundary-Consistent and Robust Artery Segmentation in DSA Sequences
summary: This paper introduces a novel Physics-Informed Loss (PIL) function designed for accurate and robust cerebral artery segmentation in Digital Subtraction Angiography (DSA) sequences. By modeling boundary interactions as an elastic process inspired by dislocation theory, PIL enforces geometric and physical consistency, overcoming limitations of conventional pixel-wise loss functions. Experimental results demonstrate PIL's superior performance in terms of sensitivity, F1 score, and boundary coherence across various segmentation architectures.

title: MTBBench: A Multimodal Sequential Clinical Decision-Making Benchmark in Oncology
summary: This paper introduces MTBBench, a novel agentic benchmark designed to simulate complex, multimodal, and longitudinal clinical decision-making in oncology, specifically within Molecular Tumor Board (MTB) environments. It reveals significant limitations in current LLMs regarding reliability, reasoning with time-resolved data, and reconciling conflicting evidence. Crucially, MTBBench also provides an agentic framework with foundation model-based tools that demonstrably enhance LLM performance on these challenging tasks.

title: Wide Area Surface Dosimetry with Conformal Scintillator Array for External Beam Radiotherapy
summary: This paper introduces a novel conformable scintillator array imaging system combined with stereovision and Cherenkov imaging for wide-area, dynamic surface dosimetry in external beam radiotherapy. The system demonstrated high dose linearity, minimal beam perturbation, angular dependence correction, and excellent agreement with film for field edge detection, along with robust inter-delivery reproducibility. This technology addresses key limitations of current in vivo dosimetry by providing spatially resolved dose maps across complex anatomical surfaces with minimal workflow impact.
